sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: This is your news tonight, the headlines.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: If the UK doesn't reply within two months, we may take them to the court of justice.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: The EU launches legal action against the UK after Boris Johnson's move to unilaterally rewrite the Northern Ireland Protocol.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Britain's first flight to Rwanda with asylum seekers never left the tarmac after last-minute legal interventions, but ministers are determined to press ahead with this controversial policy.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Ukrainian troops are still holding out in the battle for the eastern Ukrainian city of Severodonetsk, and in Brussels, defense ministers are discussing sending more weapons.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Here in The Cube, we explain why certain politicians are demanding a recount in France's legislative elections.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Good evening, welcome to the program. I'm Per Berg for Snyberg.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: The European Union has launched legal action against the UK for its decision to overhaul its post-Brexit Northern Ireland agreement with the bloc.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Brussels has accused the UK government of attempting to violate international law after Prime Minister Boris Johnson confirmed intentions to unilaterally rewrite the protocol.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: The proposed bill aims to do away with custom checks on certain goods entering Northern Ireland.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: This would supersede agreements made with the EU less than two years ago. The EU's chief Brexit negotiator Maros Sefcovic says the move jeopardizes peace and stability in the region. And the political turmoil within the UK

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: continues to rise after a last-minute decision by the European Court of Human Rights stopped the first UK asylum seeker relocation flight to Rwanda the fights was scheduled to leave late on Tuesday with up to eight asylum seekers heading to Rwanda but lawyers launched several case-by-case appeals in Parliament today British Home Secretary Priti Patel told MPs that the ECHR's decision did not mean that this action was unlawful. And despite this latest setback, the UK government says it's still committed to its new policy.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: This government will not be deterred from doing the right thing. We will not be put off by the inevitable legal last-minute challenges, nor we will allow mobs, Madam Deputy Speaker, to block removals.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Let's head live to London and speak to our reporter, Tyge Enright, who joins us now live.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Tyge, so the plane was right there on the tarmac, ready to take off. What happened?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: ready to take off. What happened? Yeah, that's right, Per. The plane had been chartered at a cost of a reported half a million pounds. It had capacity for hundreds and a planned passenger list of around 130 a few weeks ago, but that steadily dwindled down to just one before it was ultimately cancelled.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Campaigners had taken a series of legal challenges here in the UK, in the courts here, kind of umbrella legal challenges against the overall policy, as well as on behalf of the individuals who were due to be deported.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: The UK courts didn't actually reach any conclusion as to the legality of the policy, but crucially they didn't put a stay on deportations while they made up their minds as to whether it was indeed legal or not. And while many of the individuals of the people involved did succeed in convincing UK courts of their right to stay and have their asylum claims heard here in the UK. A small number failed, but in the case of one individual whose case was heard by the European Court of Human Rights, to which the UK is still a member, a stay was granted in that individual's case. And that prompted the UK courts to revise several other decisions and ultimately meant that this highly controversial flight, as you pointed out, did not get off the ground.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Now how much of a setback is this for the government's plans to send asylum seekers to Rwanda?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Well, it has to be stressed that no court has yet ruled on the legality of this policy.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: So no final decision has been reached by any court, be it here in the UK or in Strasbourg.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: It is, of course, as you point out, a highly controversial policy.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: It's faced widespread criticism here, not least from the future king of England. Prince Charles reportedly called it appalling.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: So the government for now will await these rulings.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: There is also the potential for them to appeal if they go against them.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: There is also the possibility for the UK to write this policy specifically into law, put it to a vote in Parliament, although it could face some opposition from even within the government's own ranks.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: But there is another way of looking at this, perhaps a more cynical view, that this policy is already doing what it's supposed to do, create the impression that Boris Johnson's government is fighting tooth and nail to defend its borders and its efforts are being hampered by a so-called liberal elite, deepening political divides in this country.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: That's certainly something which appeals to Boris Johnson's support base at a time when his leadership is in battle for other reasons entirely.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Per?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Taig Enright, live for us in London. Thank you, Taig.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Now, staying with the European Court of Human Rights,

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: judges have ruled that Russia is acting unlawfully in imposing statutes which allow the Kremlin to brand human rights groups as foreign agents.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Galina Polonskaya has the story.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: The European Court of Human Rights on Tuesday ordered Moscow to pay compensation to human rights groups labelled as foreign agents by Russian authorities.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: The court ruled that labelling the human rights groups as foreign agents violates rights of free assembly and association.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: The European Court agreed with the petitioners that the term foreign agent should not be used in relation to non-profit organizations, and in principle should not be used in this sense, as it has a negative connotation.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: It essentially weakens the right to freedom of expression, and it is rather difficult to argue that this term is stigmatizing.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: The use of this term has one goal – to create a so-called cooling effect on the activities of organizations, either to force them to refuse foreign funding completely or in fact to make their activities impossible.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: In 2013, the European Court of Human Rights received its first complaint from a Russian NGO labeled as a foreign agent.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: The complaints of 73 NGOs were consolidated into one case five years ago.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Among the applicants are Russia's key human rights organizations, including GOLOS and Memorial, which the authorities have already shut down.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Even a year ago, such a decision could have had some real impact on the development of the situation in Russia, at least in terms of the fact that there would be no further tightening of foreign agent laws.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: But if we look at the decision itself, considering the terms when it was made, we inform the European Court of Human Rights in our complaints that the law was discriminatory and that the persecution of non-governmental organizations under this law was of a political nature. But this European Court did not consider it necessary to note this in its decision.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: The Kremlin said it sees no point in commenting on the ruling as Russia recently adopted a law on non-enforcement on decisions by the European Court of Human Rights.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Galina Polonskaya Euronews and let's go back now to the EU's decision to launch

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: legal action against the UK for its Northern Ireland protocol action because joining me now live from Brussels is our correspondent Shona Murray Shona what more do you know about this legal action that the EU is taking? Well this is probably a long road, the start of a long road between the EU and the UK and legal infringements against the UK for non-implementation of the protocol. We heard the announcement today from Mara Sefcovic, the EU's lead Brexit negotiator and vice president of the European Commission, reviving previous legal infringements and also setting out two new ones. And they relate to, as I said there, non-implementation of the protocol, in particular, not engaging in checks on goods from Great Britain to Northern Ireland, not giving the EU any data in relation to the goods going from Great Britain to Northern Ireland. Remember, Northern Ireland is in the EU's single markets. This is a huge concern. And the EU's position is that it jeopardises the single market.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: But I got up with Mara Sefcovic today, and I asked her what else could happen here.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: I mean, in the long term, could we see, for example, the suspension of the EU-UK free trade agreement?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: We are going to do from our side, first and foremost, as I said, we are protecting single market, but today is legal action. We will be very firm, calm, but at the same time proportionate in our response. because we still want to keep the doors for negotiation open.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: But of course, if this bill is approved as it is, I cannot exclude anything and all the options have to be on the table.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: That's the EU's lead Brexit negotiator, Mara Sefovic, speaking to me earlier, making the point that while there are legal infringements against the UK for not implementing the protocol, the door is still open for negotiations to actually smooth out the practicalities around what's not working on that basis.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: But as we heard there, everything remains on the table.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Perp?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: And shown our relations between the EU and the UK during the whole Brexit process were at times, I would say, rather frosty, to say the least.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: process were at times, I would say, rather frosty, to say the least. Now, when we're back in this situation with new negotiations, legal action, would you say that we're at a situation where severe distrust is back between the two? Yeah, I don't think the trust issue was ever really resolved. I mean, obviously, the relations have been quite acrimonious for the past few years and there had been some hope in the last, let's say, few months or a year when the withdrawal agreement was signed that maybe relations could be normalized and you could see the EU and the UK work as partners, particularly after the war in Ukraine was started, the feeling being that the need for Western alliance is so important. But actually, right now, after the UK introduced this legislation, breaching the protocol, breaching international law is the consensus.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: And trust has really never been so low.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: In fact, it's been considered a historic low.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: And Mara Sefcovic made that point to me earlier.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: You said at the beginning that our relationship, especially if you're coming to such a delicate, delicate agreements like withdrawal agreement, DCA and especially the protocol is very much based on trust. And I have to say that by this draft bill introduced after 18 months of the discussion that this trust is severely damaged.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: And that's the EU's Brexit negotiator speaking to me earlier making the point that trust is severely damaged but at the same time in a more constructive tone also saying that the door remains open for negotiation to finally put this issue of the Northern Ireland Protocol to bed. Per? All right, some distrust, but the door is still open.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Shona Murray, live for us in Brussels.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Thank you so much, Shona.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: NATO defence ministers have begun a two-day summit in Brussels

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: to discuss ramping up military supplies to Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: The meeting comes as Ukraine's government once again issues a call to the West to send more heavy artillery.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg says NATO has already provided billions of dollars worth of military equipment to Kiev, as well as economic and humanitarian aid.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Sweden and Finland's applications to the security alliance is also on the table.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Meanwhile, Russia continues its relentless attacks on the eastern Ukrainian city of Severodonetsk. Kyiv's forces have been mostly pushed back to the city's azote chemical plants. Over 500 civilians are also said to be sheltering there. Humanitarian corridors have been opened to allow civilians to be brought to areas under Russian control. Now our correspondent Sasha Vakulina joins me now here in the studio.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Sasha, so if Russia now has control of more than 80% of Severodonetsk, why are the remaining Ukrainian forces still holding out, trying to defend the city?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Now the mayor of Severodonetsk said that Ukrainian forces are still in control of the industrial district, as you said, and the perimeter.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: They're making it possible to connect with the neighboring city of Lysychansk.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: He called the situation difficult but stable and adding again and again that the city has not been completely cut off.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: The Ukrainian defenders are indeed holding out there for weeks.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: They're doing that for a few reasons.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: And I have to say here that some of Ukraine's most experienced soldiers are there in the Donbas area now these few reasons are first of all of course as of now they have been tying down thousands of Russian troops for weeks in that area and that made possible for Ukrainian defenders and soldiers elsewhere to go into rather successful counteroffensive this is particularly in the south of Ukraine in the region of Herson and secondly the defenders who are there in the east in Donbas in several Donetsk they cannot go on a full-scale counter offensive against Russian forces because they are still waiting for those heavy weapons to be delivered to them pair and right now we have the defense ministers meeting in Brussels discussing just that about sending more heavy weapons. If they do decide to send in the kind of heavy artillery that the Ukrainians are asking for. Could the Ukrainians then possibly push back the Russians and even retake the city of Severodonetsk. Well Ukrainians are definitely thinking that way and they have been very open about what exactly they need. Now there are two problems here. This is not only about sending enough weapons and heavy weapons but this is also about sending it on time. Ukraine is really greatly outnumbered by Russian artillery and western aid despite all the promises is arriving way too slow and in rather small quantities for the moment. Now to give you the example how outnumbered Ukraine is the ratio there sometimes goes to 10 to 1 or even 15 to 1 in terms of artillery pieces available in combat specifically in the east where the heaviest fighting is taking place right. Now Kiev requested they just made it public the list and the requested items on that list and I'm going to just pick up one of the items there for example we see 500 tanks. Now this is the least as per presidential advisor this is what Ukraine needs to end the war. And we have 500 tanks there on the list. According to the military balance 20 21 database when it comes to the countries like the UK France and Italy all of them have between 200 to 230 tanks each so five hundred tanks that's really a lot of course this is a rather best-case scenario of you what Ukrainian authorities are hoping to receive from Western Airlines of course after all the promises that they've made the deputy defense minister of Ukraine said that as of now Kiev gets about 10% of what it needs to end this war all right we'll see what kind of decisions come out of Brussels later on tonight and tomorrow.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Sasha Vakulina, thank you so much for your time.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Now ahead of Sunday's second round of voting, the results of the National Assembly elections in France have been questioned.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Members of the left-wing alliance NOUPS have accused the interior ministry of manipulating the results.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Sophia in the Cube has been investigating.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Yes, Per, and with this extremely narrow gap separating the presidential alliance ensemble and the left-wing alliance noobs, every vote matters.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Now, according to the ministry of the interior, the current presidential alliance is currently leading by only 20,000 votes.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: But other French media, such as Le Monde, have claimed that it is actually Noops that is ahead, which as you can imagine has caused quite a bit of controversy online with certain users stating that the French authorities are manipulating the numbers.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And certain politicians such as Manuel Bompard, who is one of the key figures of the Noops alliance, took to his Twitter to state that over 265,000 votes were incorrectly counted last Sunday. Now let's take a look at how he came up with these numbers. Well it all boils down to how the Ministry of the Interior counts its votes. The politician includes in his calculations three candidates that were not counted in the NOOPS Alliance as well as certain candidates in the French overseas territories. And although it is true that the ministry did not count the votes of these candidates, Dominique Poitier, Hervé Solignac and Joël Aviragnier as Noups votes, but instead categorized them as various left party votes. And this is because these three candidates initially ran under the Noups Alliance and then withdrew their candidacy and ran as independent left-wing candidates. And in the overseas territories such as in Corsica and Guadeloupe the candidates did not join the NOUPS alliance and all ran separately against each other. So the ministry says that Macron's center-right alliance is ahead because none of these candidates were part of the noobs list.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: But Per, this controversy still raises questions about how the country counts its votes. Six days before the election, the state council said that the noobs should be counted as a single political party, while the government wanted to count each party's votes separately, which would have divided France's left even more.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Sofia in the Cube, thank you so much, Sofia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: And next round is next Sunday, so I'm sure we'll get back to that.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Now, flights in and out of Switzerland were halted for several hours this morning

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: after a technical malfunction forced its navigation service to close its airspace.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Several aircraft were diverted to neighboring countries for safety reasons.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Fights slowly resumed after the airspace closure lifted at 8.30 local time.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Suspicions of a cyber attack were quickly ruled out by authorities, and a computer failure at air traffic control is now being blamed for the interruption.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Demonstrators gathered outside the Court of Appeals in Athens,

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: where they demand harsher prison terms for members of the neo-Nazi Golden Dawn group.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Its leader, Nikos Mikhailouliakos, was returning to the court on Tuesday to overturn his sentence from 2020.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Protesters were heard chanting, keep the fascists in prison and stop the racist attacks.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: There were some of the chants heard.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Costa Rica have booked their place at the 2022 World Cup, thus completing the lineup for this year's tournament in Qatar.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Los Dicos confirmed their seventh appearance at the World Cup finals with a 1-0 victory over New Zealand.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: David Morricone reports.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: with a 1-0 victory over New Zealand.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: David Murakawa reports.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: The crowds cheered in Costa Rica as the country became the final team to qualify for the World Cup in Qatar later this year.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Costa Rica has completed the 32-nation line-up by beating New Zealand 1-0 on Tuesday, securing its place for Qatar 2022.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: The most-watched football competition will start with a group stage of 32 teams, Tuesday, securing its place for Qatar 2022. The most watched football competition will start with a group stage of 32 teams, each competing in eight groups of four.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Major European teams are considered frontrunners, but one of the main upsets this year is the absence of Italy, who have failed to qualify for their second consecutive World Cup.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Costa Rica secured its final place primarily thanks to the impressive saves from their goalkeeper and captain Keylor Navas. Many have bemoaned the decision to set the World Cup in Qatar because of human rights abuses, the treatment of workers for the building of stadiums, as well as the weather conditions. Regardless of these concerns, the World Cup kicks off in November.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: David Morriconde, Euronews.
